title: South Island the true Mainland: Cecile Meier
text:
South Island the true Mainland: Cecile Meier CECILE MEIER Last updated 15:13, September 10 2015 CECILE MEIER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Lake Pukaki is a shade of blue I didn't even know existed. 
OPINION: There are two types of New Zealanders. Those who agree the South Island is the best, and those who are lying. 
I base this on strong, scientifically gathered evidence. In March this year, I drove from Wellington to the Coromandel and back. Last week I did the same between Christchurch and Queenstown. 
The Northern jaunt included lounging on the Kapiti Coast, drinking wine and admiring the view from Ruapehu, crossing Tongariro, swimming in Taupo, surfing (or failing to) in the Coromandel and slogging up Mt Maunganui. CECILE MEIER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Aoraki - you don't get that in the North Island 
In the south, we saw lakes in shades of blue and green we never knew existed, walked through spectacular snowy peaks, drove along roads bordered by huge skies and golden tussocks, and steamed across Lake Wakatipu. 
Sure, the Coromandel region is amazing and probably the best summer holiday spot in the country with its stunning beaches and warmer temperatures. Wellington and Auckland are exciting cities, and there is more geothermal activity and cultural diversity in the north. 
But the South Island is New Zealand, only more so. The air is crisper, the water is clearer, the snow is whiter, the hills are emptier and there are more sheep. No wonder it's nicknamed The Mainland. CECILE MEIER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Driving through the South island, it's mountain after lake after rolling hills. 
Driving down south, it's mountain after lake after rolling hills and you're often alone on the road. 
North Island roads get boring quickly and the boredom is regularly replaced by rage at yet another painfully slow campervan driver who doesn't understand the concept of letting traffic pass. 
Yet, the majority of tourists arrive in New Zealand through Auckland. According to Statistics New Zealand, both islands get roughly the same number of visits throughout the year. 
Tourists don't seem to realise how much more amazing the south is. Then again, many don't seem to know New Zealand has two islands, and others probably planned to drive here from Sydney. Ad Feedback 
The fact that the islands attract the same number of visitors tells me that someone isn't doing their job right. 
It's like I had a party and let half the guests mill around my 20 square metre front garden, with its pleasant view on the beach, while the other half were allowed into my vast, Palace of Versailles-esque manicured rear garden/orchard. 
My family is coming to visit from Europe around Christmas time and they have asked me for recommendations for a road trip. They only have about five days so they would have to choose one island. 
They seem to have heard more about North Island beaches and Auckland than about all South Island destinations put together. 
Whichever island they choose to visit, they'll miss stunning sights. But if they explore the south, I will feel like they've seen what makes New Zealand most unique. 
Which island is your favourite? Where should I go in the North Island to change my mind? Comment below or email me at cecile.meier@press.co.nz or follow me on Twitter @CcileJourno - Stuff
